item.description: It's fun to run a couple of .NET applications in Docker and have them talk to each other. In this post, I use Docker Compose with a .NET Web API application and a .NET Worker Service application.

item.title: Tidy Up Your Data — Yakir Havin
item.description: One of the very first things I teach in my spreadsheets course is how to structure data properly. In order to take advantage of the power of spreadsheet functions and to do any basic analysis, the underlying data needs to be organised in the right way, and unfortunately, this is not always so intuitive to the average user. Once learned, however, it is very simple to do in practice.

item.title: We Can’t Name Variables. Now We’re Writing Prompts? | David Adamo Jr.
item.description: For years, you could get away with terrible variable names: data2, temp, x. The compiler didn’t care, but your teammates grumbled. The code ran. You shipped features. You got promoted. Writing skills? Those were for the people writing documentation or apologizing to customers when your code caused a server to self-destruct.

item.title: On being lost
item.description: There is this pressure to know what you’re doing. To have purpose, direction. To know what you’re working towards. What you care about. To be driven. There’s a reason it is idealised. Being in that state is fantastic. You have clarity. Your movements are filled with purpose. It feels like rhapsody. The greatest of works are created. But when lost, attempting to force this state on yourself is the worst disservice you can do unto yourself. Everyone has periods where they are lost. Life is in disarray, and the future holds nothing but mist. You must resist the urge to just pick any direction. To give yourself a false sense of security.

item.title: Finding My Rhythm Again - Jeremy Daly
item.description: After years of running, my heart finally told me to slow down. This is the story of how a heart condition, burnout, and a year of loss helped me find a new rhythm.

item.title: Solving Regex Crosswords with Z3
item.description: Adventures in solving regex crosswords using the SMT solver, Z3. Further adventures and misadventures in making the solver fast, in which I learn about far more Z3 features than I knew existed. Some reflections on Z3 and SMT solvers more broadly.

item.title: Nemawashi and the Meta of Meetings
item.description: Nemawashi can be seen as backroom politics, but that shouldn't be the case. The idea is that you check in before a big decision with all the stakeholders and go over all the points one on one. Making sure everyone fully understands what needs to be discussed and where everyone stands.

item.title: Foreign hackers breached a US nuclear weapons plant via SharePoint flaws
item.description: A foreign actor infiltrated the National Nuclear Security Administration’s Kansas City National Security Campus through vulnerabilities in Microsoft’s SharePoint browser-based app, raising questions about the need to solidify further federal IT/OT security protections.

item.title: The Greatness of Text Adventures
item.description: Text adventures are weird. They are so weird I don’t know how to write this article, so prepare to read something even more rambly than usual. Normally, when this happens, I decide not to publish the article. But
